Why sound matters?

Often described as the “new secondhand smoke”, noise is a major pollutant of our time, with consequences ranging from annoyance and hearing loss to early death. Poor noise management also has environmental consequences as precious resources and space are wasted.

Sounds of A busy road

Le Plateau, Mont Royal, Montréal. Credits: V. Fraisse, 2023.

TOP VIEW OF TRAFFIC IN CITY CENTER

1/5

people are highly annoyed with noise

In Quebec alone, 1 out 5 people is highly annoyed with noise and the cost of noise is estimated at 871 M$ per year. Large cities are particularly prone to conflicts around unwanted sounds due to increased densification, mixed uses, diverse economies, and nightlife. Yet, not all sound is noise. Many sound-producing activities contribute to vitality and attractiveness of cities, including transportation, tourism, leisure, outdoor festivals and other cultural events. 

positive sounds

A pocket park in the summer

NOISE

NOT ALL SOUND IS

Sounds of A busy road

Le Plateau, Mont Royal, Montréal. Credits: V. Fraisse, 2023.

00:00

MONTREAL CITY CENTER

Place des Arts, Montréal. Credits: V. Fraisse, 2023.

00:00

However, guidelines and policies rely almost exclusively on sound levels (in decibels), which, alone, fails to capture the complexity of people’s diverse experiences of urban sounds.

This complexity includes positive outcomes of sound (well-being, orientation, and community-building), the variety of stakeholders involved (across disciplines, sectors, communities and levels of government), and, critically, the social underpinnings of noise.

This is particularly true in Canada, where city-makers consider sound as an afterthought, if at all, through corrective measures when people submit complaints. Not only is this noise control strategy too little and too late, it also fails to build fairness into our cities. Indeed minoritized communities are subject to more stringent policing, and more likely to be exposed to higher noise levels.

1

Second worst environmental risk factor (after air pollution) according to the World Health Organization.
